message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of infective endocarditis, which is commonly caused by Streptococcus sanguinis. Staphylococcus epidermidis can also cause infective endocarditis, but it is less common. Streptococcus pyogenes is not typically associated with endocarditis. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a less common cause and typically causes lobar pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The petechiae under the fingernails and the tender red nodules on the fingers suggest Janeway lesions, which are seen in infective endocarditis. Among the options, only Streptococcus sanguinis is a common cause of infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest subacute bacterial endocarditis, with petechiae and finger nodules indicating septic emboli. Among the options, only Streptococcus sanguinis is commonly associated with subacute bacterial endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest infective endocarditis, and among the options, only Streptococcus sanguinis is commonly associated with infective endocarditis in patients with bicuspid aortic valve. Staphylococcus epidermidis is a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis. Streptococcus pyogenes and Streptococcus pneumoniae are less commonly associated with endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Petechiae and red nodules on the fingers suggest subacute bacterial endocarditis, and among the options, only Streptococcus sanguinis is commonly associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The petechiae and nodules on fingers are suggestive of infective endocarditis, and among the options, Streptococcus sanguinis is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in patients with bicuspid aortic valve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest infective endocarditis, which has a higher incidence in patients with bicuspid aortic valves. The presence of petechiae and tender, red nodules on the fingers suggest septic emboli. Among the options, Streptococcus sanguinis is a common cause of infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest infective endocarditis, a bacterial infection of the heart valves. Among the options, only Streptococcus sanguinis is associated with infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus epidermidis is a common skin commensal and would only cause infective endocarditis in patients with implanted medical devices. Streptococcus pyogenes and Streptococcus pneumoniae are not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest infective endocarditis, and the most likely causal organism is Streptococcus sanguinis, which is commonly associated with bicuspid aortic valve. Staphylococcus epidermidis is a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis, while Streptococcus pyogenes and Streptococcus pneumoniae are less common causes of infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the patient suggest infective endocarditis, and the nodules on the fingers are called Osler's nodes, a common finding in infective endocarditis. Among the options, Streptococcus sanguinis is the most commonly associated organism with infective endocarditis involving a bicuspid aortic valve.
